overview: From 2025-08-10 to 2025-08-17, ethereum-optimism/optimism had 7 new PRs (0 merged), 12 new issues, and 27 active contributors.

topIssues.title: op-up: support the challenger
topIssues.author: joshklop
topIssues.body: We don't need to support every challenger configuration. Will likely require packaging the cannon, op-program, and prestates with the op-up binary.

topPRs.title: Reorganize driver package
topPRs.author: teddyknox
topPRs.body:
<!--
Contributions welcome! See https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/.github/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

**Description**

Moves interfaces, Driver and SyncDeriver into separate files and renames step_test.go to sync_deriver_test.go.

topPRs.title: Add Calldata Footprint Test Draft
topPRs.author: axelKingsley
topPRs.body:
Draft.

Generates 60 simultaneous transactions with 120KB of data each.
Then, iterates over the chain and evaluates the `gasUsed` field of the block, as well as the accumulated gas and calldata of the transactions.

TODO:

- [x] Perhaps stop using the spammer pattern, and instead manually queue up the transactions (since this can be done inside a single block)
- [ ] Add test asserts after the blocks are created
- [ ] Integrate with the actual feature to confirm it works

topPRs.title: feat: network upgrade transactions for cgt
topPRs.author: tynes
topPRs.body:
**Description**

This is WIP so far but meant to show how it can work. The big todo is to
rename the feature flag with the name of the hardfork that the CGT
upgrade is included in. This does leak knowledge of CGT into the client
software so that it can optionally deploy the CGT predeploys.
It is expected that the CGT predeploys will be in the genesis if
the hardfork is active at genesis only on CGT chains.

Relevant links:
- https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/design-docs/pull/305
- https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/design-docs/pull/313
- https://github.com/defi-wonderland/optimism/pull/478

<!--
Contributions welcome! See https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/.github/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

topPRs.title: feat: Local op-geth images for kurtosis
topPRs.author: janjakubnanista
topPRs.body:
<!--
Contributions welcome! See https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/.github/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

**Description**

This PR adds support for local `op-geth` docker images to be used when running kurtosis tests.

Related to https://github.com/ethereum-optimism/optimism/issues/16975

topPRs.title: op-node: remove driver.StepEvent
topPRs.author: nonsense
topPRs.body:

topContributors.summary: axelKingsley: Focused on data footprint specifications and testing, opening a pull request for the Jovian DA Footprint (ethereum-optimism/specs#748) and a draft for a calldata footprint test (ethereum-optimism/optimism#17034). In addition to this work, which consisted mostly of new tests, they also provided feedback across 8 reviews.

niran: Focused on enhancing core protocol specifications by merging a feature to add minimum base fee specs in ethereum-optimism/specs#747. They also actively participated in code review, providing 7 comments on other pull requests. The majority of their code changes for this feature were concentrated in tests, demonstrating a focus on quality and correctness.

geoknee: Focused on providing feedback this week through active participation in code reviews and discussions. They were highly engaged, leaving 13 review comments and also commenting on one issue. This was supplemented by a single commit with minor changes.

krofax: Focused on a significant documentation effort, merging a large PR in ethereum-optimism/docs (#1716) that added comprehensive documentation on "Flashblocks for app devs and chain operators" with over 5,700 lines changed. This contribution, which also included one review comment, represented a mix of bug fixes and documentation work, primarily modifying documentation and configuration files.

blmalone: Focused on a major refactoring effort in `ethereum-optimism/superchain-ops`, merging a pull request (#1163) that removed over 57,000 lines of legacy code. They also addressed developer workflow performance by opening a PR (#1161) to handle intermittent failures.

teddyknox: Focused on improving code organization this week by landing a significant refactor in `ethereum-optimism/optimism` (#17098). This work reorganized the `driver` package, indicating a focus on improving the codebase structure within that component.
almanax-ai: No activity this week.

tynes: Focused on feature development, opening a pull request in `ethereum-optimism/optimism` (#17062) to add support for network upgrade transactions. This work modified 6 files (+119/-11 lines) and showed a strong testing discipline, with an even split between new feature code and corresponding tests.

janjakubnanista: Focused on improving the local development setup this week by opening a pull request in ethereum-optimism/optimism (#17030) to add support for local op-geth images for kurtosis. This work involved 9 commits and modifications to 16 files, primarily consisting of configuration changes and bug fixes.

guidiaz: This week, guidiaz focused on updating public-facing project information by merging a pull request in `ethereum-optimism/ethereum-optimism.github.io` (#1183). This change added the Wrapped WIT token to multiple testnets, contributing to the project's documentation and configuration.
wlawt: Focused on collaboration and code quality this week by providing feedback on pull requests. They contributed through 5 PR reviews and one additional comment.

arisarcmarket: This week, arisarcmarket focused on expanding token support within the Optimism ecosystem by opening a pull request to add the ARCv2 token to the Base network (ethereum-optimism/ethereum-optimism.github.io#1184). They also contributed to peer review by leaving 2 comments on other pull requests.

sebastianst: This week, sebastianst made substantial local code changes (+15902/-5701 lines across 368 files) that have not yet been opened for review. They also supported teammates by providing feedback through 4 code reviews and one PR comment. The local development was focused on general application code and tests.
leopoldjoy: Authored a significant volume of code this week (+936/-121
wiz-inc-a178a98b5d's activity this week was centered on collaboration, where they participated in code review discussions by leaving 3 comments on pull requests.
AmadiMichael: Focused on bugfix work this week, making several small commits across 8 files. Additionally, they participated in code reviews by providing comments on 3 pull requests.

joshklop: Contributed to the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository by identifying areas for improvement in the `op-up` tool. They created two issues to track this work, focusing on logging cleanup (#17007) and challenger support (#17005), and also provided one PR approval.

nonsense: Focused on refactoring work within the op-node, opening a pull request to remove `driver.StepEvent` in `ethereum-optimism/optimism` (#17024). This work in progress modified 16 files, with changes affecting both implementation code and tests.
ajsutton: No activity this week.

ipfsnut: This week, their activity was focused on the Ethereum Optimism ecosystem, where they opened a pull request to add the $PAGE token to the Superchain List (ethereum-optimism/ethereum-optimism.github.io#1186).
maurelian: No activity this week.

mslipper: Focused on initiating and defining the scope for the "DA Footprint Limit" initiative in the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. They laid the groundwork by creating a series of planning issues to outline the required design doc (#17009), specification (#17087), and productionization path (#16999), all tracked under a parent issue (#16998). This work indicates a clear focus on project planning and architecture for this new feature.

scagria: Prepared a significant contribution for `ethereum-optimism/ethereum-optimism.github.io`, opening PR #1185 to "Add MITY". This work involved substantial changes across 228 files (+8426/-945 lines) from 5 commits, with a focus on configuration.

anim001k: This week's focus was on improving system reliability, opening a pull request to fix an HTTP response body leak within the etherscan verification polling process (ethereum-optimism/optimism#16992).

pauldowman: Focused on planning and defining future work within the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository. They created two issues, including a proposal for a "Multi-proofs" feature (#17013) and another to support a new Go release for Cannon (#17095).
yashvardhan-kukreja: Focused on project coordination this week, creating an issue in ethereum-optimism/optimism (#17027) to organize the go-to-market tasks for enabling Flashblocks publicly.

tessr: This week, tessr contributed to the `ethereum-optimism/optimism` repository by identifying an improvement for the `op-up` developer tool, creating issue #17076 to propose adding support for standard CLI flags.
mds1: Focused on process improvement this week, authoring a postmortem for a previous incident in the ethereum-optimism/optimism repository via issue #17012.
serpixel: This week, serpixel's activity was focused on testing infrastructure, where they created an issue to port acceptance tests in the `ethereum-optimism/infra` repository (#444).

pcw109550: Focused on improving the efficiency of the sync testing infrastructure this week. They proposed adding a caching layer and batching EL requests in the `op-sync-tester` via issue ethereum-optimism/optimism#17046.
